definitions.definition: Slightly wet and often cold, usually in the air, walls, or clothes.

en-GB.text: The walls felt damp after the storm and the room smelled a little bad.

en-US.text: The basement was damp after heavy rain, so we opened windows to dry it.

definitions.definition: To make something slightly wet, for example with light rain or water in air.

en-GB.text: Please damp the cloth with water before cleaning the table very carefully.

en-US.text: First damp the sponge with water, then wash the floor in the kitchen.

en-GB.text: Damp is an adjective we use when something is a little wet but not soaked.

en-US.text: The word damp is an adjective that describes air, clothes, or walls that feel wet.

en-GB.text: In an old house, damp walls can make the rooms smell bad and feel cold.

en-US.text: If a house is damp inside, you may need better heating or to open windows.

definitions.definition: A job that is empty because someone left, and a new worker is needed.

en-GB.text: There is a vacancy for a shop assistant, so you can apply this week.

en-US.text: The company has a vacancy for a driver, and my brother wants that job.

definitions.definition: An empty room, seat, or place that someone can use, often in a building.

en-GB.text: We found a vacancy at a small hotel near the beach for one night.

en-US.text: The sign outside said there was one vacancy, so we could stay there tonight.

en-GB.text: You can check the notice board at school for a vacancy in a local shop.

en-US.text: He looked online for a vacancy at the factory because he needed full time work.

en-GB.text: The landlord told us there was a vacancy in the building for a new family.

en-US.text: The hotel showed a vacancy sign, so we knew there was an empty room.

definitions.definition: A small simple building, often made of wood, used for living or shelter.

en-GB.text: They stayed in a small hut near the lake during their summer holiday.

en-US.text: The farmer kept his tools in a small hut at the back of the field.

en-GB.text: In the countryside, we saw a shepherd living in a stone hut on the hill.

en-US.text: Children built a little hut in the woods and played inside it all afternoon.

en-GB.text: They moved from a crowded flat to a quiet hut beside the forest.

en-US.text: The family spent the weekend in a beach hut instead of their apartment in town.

shortDescription.en-GB: on or to a higher floor
shortDescription.en-US: on or to a higher floor

definitions.definition: On or to the floor above the one where you are now in a building.

en-GB.text: The children went upstairs to play in their room after dinner.

en-US.text: She ran upstairs to get her phone before leaving the house.

en-GB.text: Upstairs is an adverb that tells you where an action happens.

en-US.text: The adverb upstairs describes movement to a higher part of a building.

en-GB.text: Our bedrooms are upstairs, and the kitchen is on the ground floor.

en-US.text: The bathroom upstairs is bigger than the one next to the kitchen.

shortDescription.en-GB: make something old look new again
shortDescription.en-US: make something old look new again

definitions.definition: To make something old or damaged look good or work well again.

en-GB.text: They plan to restore the old house and paint the walls again.

en-US.text: Workers restored the broken bridge after the storm last year.

definitions.definition: To bring back a situation, right, or feeling that existed before.

en-GB.text: The new king tried to restore peace after many years of war.

en-US.text: The government restored freedom to people after the protest ended.

en-GB.text: He used tools to restore an old chair and make it strong again.

en-US.text: She learned to restore furniture using paint and new wood pieces.

en-GB.text: The museum wants to restore the painting from the 18th century.

en-US.text: Historians helped restore the old city walls for visitors to see.

en-GB.text: They will restore the kitchen to its original style with wooden beams.

en-US.text: He hopes to restore the house before winter and move in soon.

shortDescription.en-GB: a set of rooms to live in
shortDescription.en-US: a set of rooms to live in

definitions.definition: A set of rooms on one floor of a building where people live.

en-GB.text: We rented a small flat in London near the station last month.

en-US.text: He bought an apartment near his office to save time every day.

definitions.definition: Smooth and level without high or raised parts on its surface.

en-GB.text: The land behind their house is flat and easy to walk across.

en-US.text: The road is flat and straight for many miles through the desert.

en-GB.text: Flat is an adjective when we describe a surface without hills or bumps.

en-US.text: The adjective flat can describe land or things that have no curves.

en-GB.text: They live in a flat on the third floor of a tall building.

en-US.text: The apartment has two bedrooms and a big kitchen.

definitions.definition: A short light sleep time, usually during the day, not at night.

en-GB.text: He felt tired after lunch, so he took a short nap on the sofa.

en-US.text: I sometimes have a quick nap in the afternoon when work is very quiet.

en-GB.text: At the weekend, she loves a quiet nap on the bed after cleaning.

en-US.text: He closed the curtains and took a nap in the living room armchair.

en-GB.text: A short nap can help when you feel very tired or have a headache.

en-US.text: Doctors say a daytime nap should be short so you can still sleep later.

definitions.definition: To bend cloth, paper, or other things so that one part covers another.

en-GB.text: Please fold the clean clothes and put them in the drawer in your room.

en-US.text: He folded the letter carefully and placed it back into the small envelope.

en-GB.text: In many families, children help fold clothes and learn to keep rooms tidy.

en-US.text: She likes to fold clothes while watching television in the evening with her family.

en-GB.text: Fold is a common verb when we talk about clothes, paper, or simple objects.

en-US.text: People often fold paper to make cards, notes, or small simple decorations.

en-GB.text: After washing, they fold the clothes and place them neatly on the shelves.

en-US.text: Before guests arrived, he folded the blankets and put them on the sofa.

definitions.definition: To remove a cover from something so you can see or use it again.

en-GB.text: She uncovered the food on the table and called everyone to come and eat.

en-US.text: He uncovered the car with a cloth and then started to wash it carefully.

definitions.definition: To find out something that was hidden or not known by people before.

en-GB.text: The police uncovered new information that helped them solve the old case quickly.

en-US.text: Reporters uncovered a problem in the company and wrote about it in the newspaper.

en-GB.text: We use uncover as a common verb when we talk about finding or opening things.

en-US.text: Workers may uncover mistakes during checks and then report them to their manager.

en-GB.text: In the morning she likes to uncover the windows to let light into the house.

en-US.text: He uncovered the furniture after painting and checked that the floor was still clean.

definitions.definition: On the floor above the ground floor in a building, especially for living.

en-GB.text: Their first-floor flat is above a shop and looks over the busy street.

en-US.text: We rented a first-floor apartment so my grandmother does not need to climb stairs.

en-GB.text: First-floor is an adjective that describes where a room or flat is in a building.

en-US.text: We use the adjective first-floor to talk about rooms on one level of a building.

en-GB.text: They bought a first-floor flat because it feels safer than the ground floor.

en-US.text: Our first-floor apartment has a small balcony that looks over the garden behind.

definitions.definition: Working or studying for all normal hours in a week, not only some.

en-GB.text: She has a full-time job at the hospital and works five days each week.

en-US.text: He is a full-time student and spends many hours at college every day.

en-GB.text: Full-time is an adjective that describes jobs or study with many regular hours.

en-US.text: We use the adjective full-time when something continues through the whole working week.

en-GB.text: Many universities offer full-time courses for students who can study every day.

en-US.text: She started a full-time course so she could finish her degree more quickly.

en-GB.text: He changed from a part-time position to a full-time job at the same company.

en-US.text: Full-time work usually gives more money and holiday than part-time work does.

definitions.definition: The position or level of a person or thing in society or a group.

en-GB.text: His new job changed his status at work and people listened to him more.

en-US.text: Some people care too much about social status and expensive clothes or cars.

en-GB.text: In many countries, money and education can influence a person's social status.

en-US.text: Status can show how important people seem inside a community or social group.

en-GB.text: Her employment status changed from temporary worker to permanent staff last month.

en-US.text: Please write your job title and employment status on the application form.

definitions.definition: To make something longer or bigger in time, size, or area than before.

en-GB.text: They want to extend the house by adding another room at the back.

en-US.text: The school plans to extend the playground so children have more space.

definitions.definition: To make something continue to include more people, places, or things also.

en-GB.text: The company will extend its service to more towns next year too.

en-US.text: They extended the invitation to neighbours so everyone could join the party.

en-GB.text: Extend is a common verb that means to make something longer in time.

en-US.text: We often extend something when we need extra time or more space for it.

en-GB.text: My boss will extend my contract if the company gets more projects.

en-US.text: They decided to extend her working hours during the busy holiday season.

en-GB.text: We plan to extend the kitchen so there is space for a big table.

en-US.text: They extended the living room into the garden and added large windows.

definitions.definition: The business and activity of people travelling to places for holidays and interest.

en-GB.text: Tourism brings money to many seaside towns during the summer months each.

en-US.text: Tourism is important for this city because many visitors spend money in restaurants.

en-GB.text: Many local people work in tourism as guides, hotel staff, or drivers.

en-US.text: Tourism creates jobs in hotels, shops, and travel companies across the country.

en-GB.text: We chose this island because it has a lot of tourism and many activities.

en-US.text: Good tourism services can make a holiday easier and more enjoyable for families.

definitions.definition: One part of a large organisation, such as a shop, company, or government office.

en-GB.text: She works in the sales department of a big international company now.

en-US.text: Please ask in the customer service department if you need more help.

en-GB.text: He moved from the marketing department to the finance team last year.

en-US.text: Different departments in a company must work together to reach the same goals.

en-GB.text: The education department is responsible for schools and colleges in this area.

en-US.text: The health department checks restaurants to make sure the food is safe.

en-GB.text: We found cheap clothes in the children’s department of the big store.

en-US.text: The sports department sells trainers, balls, and other equipment for games there.

definitions.definition: To go away from a place or person and not stay there.

en-GB.text: We must leave the house early to catch the first train today.

en-US.text: Please leave the room quietly when the lesson is finished for today.

definitions.definition: To stop working at a job, company, or school, often for another plan.

en-GB.text: She will leave her job next month to start her own business.

en-US.text: He left school early to find work and help his family more.

definitions.definition: Time when you are officially allowed to be away from work or duty.

en-GB.text: She is on maternity leave and will return to work in six months.

en-US.text: He took a week of leave to rest and visit his parents.

en-GB.text: Leave is a common verb that means to go away from a place.

en-US.text: We use leave when we stop being in a place, group, or situation.

en-GB.text: He plans to leave his company if he finds a better position.

en-US.text: Her manager approved her leave so she could attend a family wedding.

definitions.definition: A plan or suggestion that someone puts forward so others can discuss or accept.

en-GB.text: The manager liked her proposal to change the office times and save money.

en-US.text: We will read each proposal and choose the best idea for the project.

definitions.definition: An offer of marriage when someone asks another person to become their husband or wife.

en-GB.text: His marriage proposal was simple, and he asked her during a quiet dinner.

en-US.text: She accepted his proposal when he asked her to marry him in Paris.

en-GB.text: Her proposal to train new staff was accepted by the company directors.

en-US.text: They wrote a proposal for a new project and sent it to the boss.

en-GB.text: The council discussed a proposal to build a new library in town.

en-US.text: Parliament voted on a proposal to change the tax rules for families.

en-GB.text: Friends were very happy when they heard about the couple's marriage proposal.

en-US.text: After the proposal, they planned their wedding with close family and friends.

shortDescription.en-GB: walk or drive to watch area
shortDescription.en-US: walk or drive to watch area

definitions.definition: A group of people or police who check an area regularly for safety.

en-GB.text: The night patrol checked each door of the building before leaving carefully.

en-US.text: A police patrol drives through the neighbourhood to stop crime there at night.

definitions.definition: To walk or drive around an area to watch it and keep it safe.

en-GB.text: Officers patrol the streets near the stadium during big football matches there.

en-US.text: Security guards patrol the shopping center to help customers feel safe inside.

en-GB.text: Joining a street patrol can be a full-time job for some officers.

en-US.text: Many people work on patrol for the police or private security companies.

en-GB.text: The city started a special patrol to reduce crime in the park at night.

en-US.text: Police patrol busy areas to keep order and protect local businesses there.

en-GB.text: The coast guard patrols the sea in boats to help ships in trouble.

en-US.text: Highway patrol officers drive along the motorway to check traffic and help drivers.

definitions.definition: To guess a number, size, or amount using some facts and careful thinking.

en-GB.text: The builder will estimate the price of the work before we agree.

en-US.text: Can you estimate how long the journey will take in bad traffic today.

definitions.definition: A number, time, or cost that you give as your careful guess.

en-GB.text: The company sent an estimate for the new windows and doors yesterday.

en-US.text: We asked three shops for an estimate before choosing the cheapest offer.

en-GB.text: Estimate is a common verb that means to guess a number or amount carefully.

en-US.text: We often estimate numbers in daily life, like guessing costs or travel time.

en-GB.text: In my job I must estimate how many workers we need for each project.

en-US.text: The manager estimates the time for each task before giving work to staff.

en-GB.text: Before buying a car, we estimate our monthly costs for fuel and insurance.

en-US.text: Families estimate their bills each month so they know how much to save.

shortDescription.en-GB: very different or facing another side
shortDescription.en-US: very different or facing another side

definitions.definition: Completely different from something else in meaning, direction, position, or general feeling.

en-GB.text: His opinion is the opposite of mine; he thinks the idea is bad.

en-US.text: The two paintings show opposite moods, one very happy and one very sad.

definitions.definition: Across from something, facing it on the other side of a space or road.

en-GB.text: The bank is opposite the station, so you can see it from the platform.

en-US.text: Our house is opposite a park, and we watch children playing there.

en-GB.text: Opposite is an adjective when two things are very different from each other.

en-US.text: We use the adjective opposite to talk about very different ideas or qualities.

en-GB.text: The preposition opposite describes a place across from something, usually facing it.

en-US.text: In class, I sat opposite my friend, so we could see each other easily.

definitions.definition: Not helpful or effective, so it cannot do the job or solve the problem.

en-GB.text: This old phone is useless because the battery dies after only a few minutes.

en-US.text: The map was useless in the dark, so we asked a man for directions.

en-GB.text: Useless is an adjective that describes something that does not help you at all.

en-US.text: We use the adjective useless for things that cannot do what we need.

en-GB.text: His advice was useless, and the situation stayed the same after the meeting.

en-US.text: The meeting felt useless because nobody listened or changed their behavior afterwards.

shortDescription.en-GB: very keen and excited to do something
shortDescription.en-US: very keen and excited to do something

definitions.definition: Very interested and excited about doing something, because you really want it to happen.

en-GB.text: The children were eager to open their presents as soon as they woke up.

en-US.text: She is eager to start her new job and meet her coworkers next week.

en-GB.text: Eager is an adjective we use when someone wants to do something very much.

en-US.text: The adjective eager describes people who are ready and happy to start something.

en-GB.text: He felt eager before the trip and packed his bag days before leaving.

en-US.text: Students were eager and excited as they waited for the holiday to begin.

definitions.definition: In or towards the area that is between south and east on a map.

en-GB.text: Our town is in the southeast part of the country, near the coast.

en-US.text: They travelled to a village in the southeast region to visit family there.

en-GB.text: We use southeast as an adjective for towns in the southeast part of a country.

en-US.text: The southeast coast has many beautiful beaches and small towns for tourists.

en-GB.text: This region has warm seas and hills in the southeast corner of the island.

en-US.text: Many rivers in the southeast area flow slowly through forests and green farmland.

shortDescription.en-GB: from or in the south part
shortDescription.en-US: from or in the south part

definitions.definition: Located in or coming from the south part of a country, region, or area.

en-GB.text: Many southern towns are warmer than northern ones because they are closer to the equator.

en-US.text: She grew up in a southern city and speaks with a gentle local accent.

en-GB.text: Southern is an adjective that describes people or places from the south of a region.

en-US.text: We talk about southern food, music, or weather when it comes from the south.

en-GB.text: The southern coast has long beaches and small fishing villages along the sea.

en-US.text: Many tourists visit the southern islands because they have warm seas and clear skies.

definitions.definition: From or connected with hot, wet parts of the world near the equator.

en-GB.text: They enjoyed the tropical island with its warm sea and tall palm trees.

en-US.text: A tropical climate usually has heavy rain and very high temperatures all year.

en-GB.text: Tropical is an adjective that describes plants, animals, or places in hot wet areas.

en-US.text: We use the adjective tropical for fruit, islands, or forests in very warm climates.

en-GB.text: The country has tropical forests with many different trees and colourful birds.

en-US.text: Some tropical islands have white sand beaches and green mountains in the center.

en-GB.text: People in tropical countries often wear light clothes because the weather is very hot.

en-US.text: Tropical storms can bring strong winds and heavy rain to coastal towns quickly.

definitions.definition: Receiving money for work or service, not free or done without any payment.

en-GB.text: He found a paid job in a café instead of working there as a volunteer.

en-US.text: She prefers paid work because she needs money to support her family.

en-GB.text: Paid is an adjective that shows someone gets money for their work or time.

en-US.text: We use the adjective paid to describe work that gives money, not experience only.

en-GB.text: She moved from unpaid training to a paid position in the same office.

en-US.text: Many students look for paid internships to get experience and earn some money.

en-GB.text: Our bills are paid, so we do not owe any money this month.

en-US.text: He checked which invoices were paid and which companies still needed to send money.

shortDescription.en-GB: about people, not animals or machines
shortDescription.en-US: about people, not animals or machines

definitions.definition: Related to people, not animals or machines, and showing normal feelings or behaviour.

en-GB.text: Making mistakes is human, so do not feel bad if you are wrong sometimes.

en-US.text: The story shows human problems like love, fear, money, and many family arguments.

en-GB.text: Human is an adjective when we talk about normal people and their everyday lives.

en-US.text: We use the adjective human to describe bodies, feelings, or problems of people.

en-GB.text: Many laws try to protect human rights and basic freedoms in modern societies.

en-US.text: Human behavior in groups can change when people feel angry, scared, or very excited.

shortDescription.en-GB: happy like at a party or holiday
shortDescription.en-US: happy like at a party or holiday

definitions.definition: Looking or feeling bright and happy because of a party, holiday, or special event.

en-GB.text: The streets looked festive with lights, music, colourful decorations, and many people smiling.

en-US.text: People wore festive clothes to the party and brought food to share with friends.

en-GB.text: Festive is an adjective that describes happy parties, colours, food, and holiday activities.

en-US.text: We say a place feels festive when there are bright lights, music, and happy people.

en-GB.text: Town centres often look festive at Christmas with trees, lights, and street markets.

en-US.text: Families create a festive atmosphere at holidays by cooking special meals and decorating homes.

definitions.definition: Very big in size or area, much larger than you usually see.

en-GB.text: From the hill we saw a vast forest that seemed to go on forever.

en-US.text: The desert is vast, and you can drive for hours without seeing any houses.

en-GB.text: Vast is an adjective we use to describe something very, very big in size.

en-US.text: You can use the adjective vast when an area or number is extremely big.

en-GB.text: The vast lake lay between the mountains and looked like a silver mirror in sunlight.

en-US.text: A vast plain stretched in front of us, with no trees or houses anywhere.

definitions.definition: Very special and holy, connected with God, religion, or something people deeply respect.

en-GB.text: The temple is a sacred place where many people go to pray quietly.

en-US.text: They believe the river is sacred and must be kept clean and protected.

en-GB.text: Sacred is an adjective for things that are holy or very special in religion.

en-US.text: We use the adjective sacred to describe places, objects, or stories that are holy.

en-GB.text: The festival is sacred to many families, and they follow old traditions each year.

en-US.text: In some cultures, certain animals are sacred and people never kill or eat them.

definitions.definition: A strong feeling of worry or pressure, often because of problems or too much work.

en-GB.text: She felt a lot of stress before the exam and could not sleep well.

en-US.text: Long hours at work gave him stress and he became tired and unhappy.

definitions.definition: To make someone feel worried and tense because there is too much to do.

en-GB.text: Do not stress the children with too many activities after school every day.

en-US.text: The deadline stressed everyone, and people worked late to finish the project.

en-GB.text: Too much stress at work can lead to mistakes and health problems over time.

en-US.text: Managers should reduce stress by giving clear tasks and fair breaks during the day.

en-GB.text: He spoke about his stress and felt better after sharing his worries with friends.

en-US.text: Talking to a friend is one way to deal with stress and feel calmer.

en-GB.text: Doctors say long stress can raise blood pressure and hurt the heart and body.

en-US.text: Some clinics offer classes to manage stress through exercise, breathing, and talking groups.

definitions.definition: Liking someone or something very much, often in a warm or gentle way.

en-GB.text: She is very fond of her grandparents and visits them every weekend.

en-US.text: He is fond of cooking, and he enjoys making big meals for friends.

en-GB.text: Fond is an adjective that describes a warm, loving feeling towards a person or thing.

en-US.text: We say someone is fond of something when they enjoy it again and again.

en-GB.text: As a child, he grew fond of music and played the piano every day.

en-US.text: She became very fond of her new classmates and stayed in touch with them.

definitions.definition: Feeling relaxed and not angry, excited, or afraid, even when something is difficult.

en-GB.text: She felt calm before the exam because she had studied well all week.

en-US.text: He stayed calm during the storm and helped his family close all the windows.

en-GB.text: Deep breathing can help you feel calm again when you are nervous or scared.

en-US.text: After the argument, they took a walk to become calm and talk more softly.

definitions.definition: A quiet, relaxed feeling without worry, anger, or loud noise around you.

en-GB.text: The calmness of the empty beach helped her forget her busy life for awhile.

en-US.text: He enjoyed the calmness in the park early in the morning before work.

en-GB.text: Soft music can bring calmness when people feel nervous or worried about something important.

en-US.text: Many people go for a walk to find calmness and clear their minds after work.

definitions.definition: To talk with too much pride about yourself, your things, or your achievements.

en-GB.text: He likes to boast about his new car and how fast it can go.

en-US.text: She often boasts that she is the best student in the whole class.

definitions.definition: Something you are proud of and like to talk about to other people.

en-GB.text: His main boast is that he once met a famous singer after a concert.

en-US.text: Her cooking is a family boast, and relatives always ask for her dishes.

en-GB.text: People sometimes boast when they feel insecure and want others to notice their successes.

en-US.text: It is better to stay modest than to boast all the time about yourself.

definitions.definition: Happening in a bad or unlucky way that makes people sad or causes problems.

en-GB.text: It was unfortunate that the party was cancelled because many guests had travelled far.

en-US.text: An unfortunate mistake in the report made the company look unprofessional to clients.

en-GB.text: Unfortunate is an adjective for bad situations that make you wish they were different.

en-US.text: We describe an event as unfortunate when something went wrong in a sad way.

en-GB.text: Losing his job was unfortunate, and his family felt worried about the future.

en-US.text: She thought it was unfortunate that her friend could not join the trip.

definitions.definition: A strong feeling of liking someone in a romantic way, usually without telling them.

en-GB.text: As a teenager, she had a crush on a boy in her class.

en-US.text: He told his friend about his crush but was too shy to speak to her.

en-GB.text: Many young people keep their crush secret because they are afraid of being rejected.

en-US.text: Having a crush can feel exciting and scary at the same time for teenagers.

definitions.definition: To enjoy someone or something, or think that they are good or pleasant.

en-GB.text: I like this teacher because she explains things clearly and listens to questions patiently.

en-US.text: They like playing football after school and often meet in the park together.

definitions.definition: Similar to something or someone in appearance, sound, or the way they act.

en-GB.text: My brother looks like my father, but he is taller and has darker hair.

en-US.text: This soup tastes like the one my grandmother used to make for us.

en-GB.text: Like is a very common verb we use to talk about our interests and preferences.

en-US.text: Children often say they like certain games or foods and dislike others strongly.

en-GB.text: When you say you like someone, it can mean friendship or sometimes romantic interest.

en-US.text: He did not know if she liked him as a friend or something more.

en-GB.text: We use like as a preposition to compare one person or thing with another.

en-US.text: The clouds today look like soft cotton above the city and the river.

definitions.definition: To breathe out slowly and loudly, often because you are tired, sad, or relieved.

en-GB.text: She sighed when she saw the long queue at the bank on Monday morning.

en-US.text: He sighed with relief when he heard that his exam result was good.

definitions.definition: A long, often loud breath that shows you are tired, sad, or relieved.

en-GB.text: With a deep sigh, the teacher sat down and started to check the tests.

en-US.text: Her sigh told us she was disappointed about the cancelled trip to the beach.

en-GB.text: Sigh is a common verb that shows feelings through the way we breathe out.

en-US.text: People sigh when they are bored, tired, worried, or sometimes happily relieved.

en-GB.text: You could hear the sighs in the room when the teacher gave extra homework.

en-US.text: Her long sigh after the phone call showed she was sad and disappointed.

definitions.definition: Feeling very worried or under pressure, and finding it hard to relax.

en-GB.text: She felt stressed before the interview and could not eat any breakfast.

en-US.text: He was stressed about money and often woke up in the night thinking.

en-GB.text: Stressed is an adjective we use when someone has too many problems or worries.

en-US.text: People feel stressed when they cannot control events and everything seems difficult.

en-GB.text: Many workers are stressed because they have long hours and heavy responsibilities at work.

en-US.text: If employees are stressed for a long time, it can hurt their health and performance.

en-GB.text: She told her friend she was stressed and needed help to organise her tasks.

en-US.text: When you feel stressed, simple things like walking or talking can sometimes help.

definitions.definition: Something you say or write to give an opinion or reaction about something.

en-GB.text: Her comment about the film was very kind and made the actors smile.

en-US.text: He posted a comment under the article to share his ideas with others.

definitions.definition: To say or write something to give your opinion about a situation or subject.

en-GB.text: The teacher commented on my homework and gave advice to improve my writing.

en-US.text: Experts commented on the news story and explained what it might mean for families.

en-GB.text: A short comment can sometimes explain your main idea more clearly than a long speech.

en-US.text: Teachers often ask students to write a comment to show they understood the text.

en-GB.text: Many websites allow users to leave a comment after reading an article or watching a video.

en-US.text: On social media, people sometimes write a quick comment instead of a long message.

shortDescription.en-GB: show or explain how something works
shortDescription.en-US: show or explain how something works

definitions.definition: To show or explain how something works or how to do something, often by example.

en-GB.text: The teacher demonstrated the experiment, and then the students tried it by themselves.

en-US.text: She demonstrated how to use the new software step by step on the screen.

en-GB.text: Demonstrate is a common verb in school or work when people show how to do tasks.

en-US.text: We often demonstrate a skill slowly so other people can watch and copy the actions.

en-GB.text: In science class, the teacher will demonstrate safe ways to mix the different liquids.

en-US.text: Language teachers demonstrate new words using pictures, actions, and simple example sentences.

en-GB.text: A clear graph can demonstrate your main idea better than many lines of text.

en-US.text: During the meeting, she demonstrated her idea with a short story and simple drawing.

definitions.definition: To tell a story, film, or event in words, often in a clear order.

en-GB.text: In the film, a voice narrates the story and explains what the people are doing.

en-US.text: Grandfather narrated stories from his childhood while the children listened quietly on the floor.

en-GB.text: Narrate is a less common verb that means to tell a story in detail.

en-US.text: We sometimes ask students to narrate a short event from their day in class.

en-GB.text: When you narrate clearly, listeners can follow your ideas and understand the order of events.

en-US.text: Good speakers narrate slowly and use pauses so their ideas stay clear and interesting.

en-GB.text: In many books, one person narrates everything that happens to the other characters.

en-US.text: Teachers may ask children to narrate a story they have read in their own words.

definitions.definition: Able to make people believe something or do something by giving good reasons.

en-GB.text: Her persuasive speech helped students understand the problem and support the new school project.

en-US.text: A persuasive letter can change someone's mind and make them agree with your idea.

en-GB.text: Persuasive is an adjective for language that makes people agree or change their minds.

en-US.text: A persuasive speaker uses clear examples and simple words to convince the audience.

en-GB.text: You need persuasive reasons if you want your parents to support your idea.

en-US.text: Good writers use persuasive language when they want to change the reader's opinion.

definitions.definition: To give someone information or facts so they know about something important.

en-GB.text: Please inform the teacher if you are ill and cannot come to class.

en-US.text: The company will inform customers by email if prices change next month.

en-GB.text: Inform is a common verb that means to tell someone important facts or news.

en-US.text: Teachers inform students about exams so they can prepare in a calm way.

en-GB.text: A good report should inform the reader clearly about the main points.

en-US.text: Speakers inform the audience and then answer questions at the end of the talk.

en-GB.text: News programmes try to inform people about events happening around the world.

en-US.text: Websites and newspapers inform readers, but information is not always complete or correct.

definitions.definition: To decide something is true after thinking about all the information you have.

en-GB.text: After reading the report, we concluded that the plan was not safe enough.

en-US.text: The police concluded the fire was an accident after checking all the evidence.

en-GB.text: You should conclude your talk with a clear sentence that repeats the main idea.

en-US.text: Writers often conclude an essay by summarising their points in a short paragraph.

definitions.definition: Used to show you are almost certain something is true or will happen.

en-GB.text: Surely you remember her, she visited our house many times last year.

en-US.text: Surely they will call us soon because the news is very important today.

en-GB.text: Surely is an adverb we use when we strongly believe something is true.

en-US.text: You can say surely before a sentence to show you are almost certain.

en-GB.text: Surely we can find a simple solution if everyone works together calmly.

en-US.text: Surely you can see that listening carefully will help us solve this problem.

shortDescription.en-GB: say firmly that something must happen
shortDescription.en-US: say firmly that something must happen

definitions.definition: To say strongly that something must happen or is true, and not change your mind.

en-GB.text: My parents insist that I finish my homework before I play computer games.

en-US.text: He insisted on paying the bill even when his friends tried to stop him.

en-GB.text: Insist is a common verb we use when someone keeps asking very strongly.

en-US.text: Parents sometimes insist that children return home early on school nights.

en-GB.text: He will insist on his opinion even when other people disagree with him.

en-US.text: She insisted that the meeting should start on time despite the bad weather.

definitions.definition: To think something is true without checking, often because it seems very likely.

en-GB.text: Do not assume he is angry; maybe he is just tired after work today.

en-US.text: We assumed the shop was open, but it was closed when we arrived there.

en-GB.text: People sometimes assume they are right and do not listen to other opinions.

en-US.text: It is better to ask questions than to assume you understand everything perfectly.

definitions.definition: To make something better or more complete by going well with it.

en-GB.text: The blue scarf complements her dress and makes the whole outfit look nicer.

en-US.text: Rice complements the spicy meat and makes the meal feel complete and filling.

definitions.definition: Something that completes or improves another thing by going well with it.

en-GB.text: The salad is a perfect complement to the grilled chicken at dinner.

en-US.text: Her calm manner is a good complement to his more active personality.

en-GB.text: Pictures can complement spoken words and help listeners understand an idea more easily.

en-US.text: A short story may complement a talk and make the message more memorable.

en-GB.text: In grammar, a complement is a word or phrase that completes the meaning of another.

en-US.text: Teachers may explain that some verbs need a complement, like an object or phrase.

definitions.definition: To make something more tight, so it is harder to move, open, or change.

en-GB.text: Tighten the lid on the jar so the food stays fresh for longer.

en-US.text: He tightened the belt on his trousers so they would not fall down.

en-GB.text: Workers often tighten screws or nuts when they build or repair machines.

en-US.text: You may need to tighten the handle if the door feels loose and shaky.

en-GB.text: If a lid is not tight, you must tighten it so nothing spills out.

en-US.text: He used a tool to tighten the metal wire until it felt strong and firm.

shortDescription.en-GB: have your home in a place
shortDescription.en-US: have your home in a place

definitions.definition: To have your home in a place and stay there most of the time.

en-GB.text: They live in a small flat near the river in the city centre.

en-US.text: I live with my family in a house close to the cinema and park.

definitions.definition: Broadcast or happening now, not recorded earlier or shown from the past.

en-GB.text: We watched a live football match on television with commentary from a famous player.

en-US.text: The band played a live concert in the park and many people came.

en-GB.text: Many people live in cities, but some still live in small country villages.

en-US.text: She wants to live near her work so she can walk there each morning.

en-GB.text: We enjoyed the live music at the festival more than the recorded songs.

en-US.text: Watching a live show at the theatre feels very different from watching television.

definitions.definition: To move your mouth so it turns up, showing you are happy or friendly.

en-GB.text: She smiled when she saw the surprise cake on the table there.

en-US.text: He smiled at the baby and waved his hand to make her laugh.

definitions.definition: The happy or friendly look on your face when you move your mouth up.

en-GB.text: His big smile made everyone in the room feel relaxed and welcome.

en-US.text: Her smile was wide and bright when she heard the good news.

en-GB.text: People often smile when they meet friends or say hello to neighbours.

en-US.text: Babies smile early, and parents feel happy when they see this first smile.

en-GB.text: A simple smile can show kindness and make another person feel less nervous.

en-US.text: When she walked into the room, her smile made everyone feel more relaxed.

definitions.definition: To open something that was folded, so it becomes flat or longer again.

en-GB.text: She unfolded the letter and read the long message from her friend.

en-US.text: He unfolded the map on the table and looked for the small village.

en-GB.text: You unfold a piece of paper when you want to read what is inside.

en-US.text: She unfolded the blanket and laid it carefully on the grass for a picnic.

en-GB.text: The story begins slowly, and the main problem starts to unfold later.

en-US.text: As events unfold, the characters in the book learn more about each other.

shortDescription.en-GB: be brave enough to do something
shortDescription.en-US: be brave enough to do something

definitions.definition: To be brave enough to do something difficult, scary, or unusual for you.

en-GB.text: She did not dare to speak in front of the large group of strangers.

en-US.text: He dared to ask for help when the problem became too big for him.

en-GB.text: Many people dare to try new sports when they travel to another country.

en-US.text: You might dare to speak English in public even if you feel shy.

en-GB.text: It was a brave dare to climb the high rock without any help.

en-US.text: Her friends admired her because she dared to move to another country alone.

definitions.definition: To laugh at someone or joke in a way that can make them upset.

en-GB.text: Do not tease your sister about her glasses; it hurts her feelings.

en-US.text: The children teased him at school, and he felt lonely and sad.

en-GB.text: Children sometimes tease each other in class, but teachers tell them to stop.

en-US.text: It is fine to joke, but you should not tease people in a cruel way.

en-GB.text: Being teased every day can make a person feel very sad and alone.

en-US.text: She cried because the other students teased her about her new haircut.

en-GB.text: Brothers and sisters sometimes tease each other, but they still care deeply.

en-US.text: He likes to tease his cousin, but he stops when she looks unhappy.

definitions.definition: To begin or appear, especially when a problem, chance, or situation starts.

en-GB.text: If any questions arise during the talk, please write them on this paper.

en-US.text: Problems can arise when people do not listen carefully to each other.

en-GB.text: New ideas often arise when people from different countries work together in teams.

en-US.text: If difficulties arise, talk about them early before they become very serious.

definitions.definition: To make clothes or other things from wool using two long needles.

en-GB.text: My grandmother knits warm socks for us every winter while watching television.

en-US.text: She learned to knit a scarf for her friend in her free time.

en-GB.text: In winter many people like to wear knitted hats, scarves, and gloves.

en-US.text: She decided to knit a jumper because she could not find one she liked.

en-GB.text: Older relatives sometimes knit while they watch television or listen to the radio.

en-US.text: He wants to learn how to knit simple things like scarves and hats.

en-GB.text: Knitting is a quiet hobby that can help people relax after work.

en-US.text: Many clubs meet weekly so members can knit together and share patterns.

definitions.definition: To move food or liquid around with a spoon or stick, usually while cooking.

en-GB.text: Please stir the soup slowly so it does not burn at the bottom.

en-US.text: He stirred the coffee with a spoon until the sugar disappeared completely.

en-GB.text: Remember to stir the paint before you use it so the colour is even.

en-US.text: If you stir slowly, you will not spill the drink on the table.

en-GB.text: You need to stir the sauce while it cooks so it does not stick.

en-US.text: She stirred sugar into her tea until it tasted sweet enough for her.

shortDescription.en-GB: movement that shows feeling or idea
shortDescription.en-US: movement that shows feeling or idea

definitions.definition: A movement of your hand, arm, or head to show a feeling or idea.

en-GB.text: She made a friendly gesture by waving when she saw her neighbours outside.

en-US.text: His gesture of giving flowers was very kind and made her smile.

definitions.definition: To move your hand, arm, or head to show a feeling or idea.

en-GB.text: The coach gestured to the players to come closer and listen carefully.

en-US.text: He gestured towards the door to show us which way to go out.

en-GB.text: A small gesture like a smile or wave can show care and friendship.

en-US.text: She used a gentle gesture to calm the child when he started to cry.

en-GB.text: Teachers sometimes use gesture when they explain new words or difficult ideas.

en-US.text: In many cultures people gesture a lot while speaking to make their ideas clearer.

definitions.definition: To ask politely for something to be given, done, or allowed to you.

en-GB.text: You must request a day off from your manager before you book tickets.

en-US.text: She requested a different room because the first one was too noisy.

definitions.definition: An act of asking politely for something to be given, done, or allowed.

en-GB.text: We made a request for more time to finish the important project.

en-US.text: The teacher accepted his request to leave class early for a doctor visit.

en-GB.text: You can request help from staff in a shop if you cannot find something.

en-US.text: Passengers may request extra water or blankets from the flight attendants.

en-GB.text: The word request is useful in emails when you politely ask for information.

en-US.text: On forms you may see a space to write a special request or note.

en-GB.text: A clear request helps other people understand exactly what you need from them.

en-US.text: She made a polite request at the meeting instead of speaking in an angry way.

definitions.definition: Fair and sensible, not too extreme, so most people think it is acceptable.

en-GB.text: The price of the meal was reasonable, so we decided to eat there again.

en-US.text: It is reasonable to ask for help when the work is too difficult.

en-GB.text: Reasonable is an adjective we use when something seems fair and not too strong.

en-US.text: Most people think a reasonable rule is one that feels clear and fair.

en-GB.text: She made a reasonable suggestion that the meeting should finish a little earlier.

en-US.text: It sounds reasonable to wait until tomorrow, but we must decide very soon.

definitions.definition: An act of showing or explaining how something works or how to do it.

en-GB.text: The science teacher gave a demonstration of the experiment before we tried it ourselves.

en-US.text: We watched a cooking demonstration and learned how to make a simple soup.

definitions.definition: A public meeting or march where people show they support or oppose something.

en-GB.text: Many students joined a demonstration in the city centre to ask for cheaper buses.

en-US.text: The police watched the demonstration to make sure it stayed peaceful and safe.

en-GB.text: In class we often see a demonstration before we try a difficult experiment ourselves.

en-US.text: A clear demonstration by the teacher helps students understand each step of the task.

en-GB.text: A short demonstration with pictures can explain your main idea better than long text.

en-US.text: During his talk, he used a simple demonstration to show how the machine worked.

en-GB.text: The council listened after a peaceful demonstration outside the main building last week.

en-US.text: People organised a demonstration in front of the government offices to demand changes.

definitions.definition: A conversation between two or more people, often in books, films, or lessons.

en-GB.text: The students read a short dialogue and then practised it in pairs in class.

en-US.text: We listened to a dialog about travel and answered questions on a worksheet.

en-GB.text: In language lessons, teachers often use dialogue to help students practise speaking naturally together.

en-US.text: The exam includes a dialog where two students discuss school life and weekend activities.

en-GB.text: Dialogue in a story can show feelings and ideas without long explanations from the writer.

en-US.text: Good dialog helps characters share ideas clearly so the audience understands the situation easily.

en-GB.text: Some novels use lots of dialogue, while others use more description and little direct speech.

en-US.text: Plays are mainly dialog, so actors must remember all the words their characters say.

definitions.definition: To shine light on something so it becomes bright and easy for people to see.

en-GB.text: Street lamps illuminate the road at night so drivers can see clearly.

en-US.text: A bright moon illuminated the path through the forest during our evening walk.

definitions.definition: To help people understand something by explaining or giving clear, simple examples.

en-GB.text: The teacher used pictures to illuminate the story and make difficult ideas easier to understand.

en-US.text: Examples from real life illuminated the lesson and helped students remember the new grammar.

en-GB.text: We use illuminate when we talk about lights that make dark places bright at night.

en-US.text: The verb illuminate is useful when describing how lamps or screens make things easier to see.

en-GB.text: Good examples can illuminate a difficult idea and help listeners understand it more quickly.

en-US.text: Writers sometimes illuminate a theme by describing one clear situation from everyday life.

en-GB.text: Modern phones can illuminate the room with a bright screen or built in torch.

en-US.text: Street lights that use solar power illuminate roads while saving energy for the city.

definitions.definition: To show that something is important by drawing attention to it clearly.

en-GB.text: Use a marker to highlight new words in your book so you can review them.

en-US.text: The report highlights three main problems the company must fix this year.

definitions.definition: The best, most interesting, or most enjoyable part of an event or period.

en-GB.text: The highlight of the trip was visiting the old castle on the hill.

en-US.text: Meeting her favourite singer was the highlight of her holiday in New York.

en-GB.text: Teachers highlight important words on the board so students know what to remember.

en-US.text: Use a highlighter to mark and highlight key ideas in your textbook before exams.

en-GB.text: In your talk, highlight three main points so the audience can follow easily.

en-US.text: The article highlights the dangers of pollution and suggests simple changes for families.

en-GB.text: Television news often highlights one big story at the beginning of the programme.

en-US.text: The website highlights popular videos on the front page to attract more visitors.

definitions.definition: Informal talk about other people's private lives, often stories that may not be true.

en-GB.text: Office gossip can hurt people because stories spread quickly and are not always correct.

en-US.text: He tried to ignore the gossip about his friend and focus on the facts.

definitions.definition: To talk about other people's private lives, often in a way that is unkind.

en-GB.text: They gossiped about their neighbour's new boyfriend while drinking tea in the kitchen.

en-US.text: Students sometimes gossip about teachers after class instead of going straight home.

en-GB.text: Gossip can pass ideas and stories quickly, but they are not always correct or fair.

en-US.text: Instead of gossip, it is better to share facts and your own honest feelings.

en-GB.text: Some magazines write gossip about famous people and sell many copies each week.

en-US.text: Online gossip sites often publish stories about celebrities without checking them carefully.

en-GB.text: Too much gossip can damage friendships because people stop trusting each other.

en-US.text: They promised not to share gossip about their friends and to speak kindly instead.

shortDescription.en-GB: say something is true or correct
shortDescription.en-US: say something is true or correct

definitions.definition: To say or show that something is true, correct, or will definitely happen.

en-GB.text: Please confirm your booking by email so we know you are coming.

en-US.text: The teacher confirmed the exam date and wrote it clearly on the board.

en-GB.text: We confirm plans so everyone knows the time and place for the meeting.

en-US.text: You should confirm your ticket online before you travel to avoid any problems.

en-GB.text: The second experiment confirmed their idea and showed that the first result was right.

en-US.text: Several witnesses confirmed his story, so the judge believed what he had said.

definitions.definition: Official decision to forgive someone, so they are not punished for a crime.

en-GB.text: The president gave a pardon to several prisoners before leaving office.

en-US.text: After many years, the man finally received a pardon for the old crime.

definitions.definition: To forgive someone for something wrong, or excuse them politely in conversation.

en-GB.text: Please pardon the mess in our house; we have just moved in today.

en-US.text: He pardoned his friend for the mistake and did not speak about it again.

en-GB.text: People sometimes say pardon when they did not hear a sentence and want it repeated.

en-US.text: In polite conversation, you can say Pardon me when you need someone to repeat.

en-GB.text: A court may discuss a pardon when new information shows that a prisoner is innocent.

en-US.text: The governor granted a pardon after lawyers found serious mistakes in the original case.

en-GB.text: Sometimes a simple apology is enough for friends to pardon each other and move on.

en-US.text: Parents often pardon small mistakes because they know their children are still learning.

definitions.definition: A careful search for facts about something, especially when a crime or problem happens.

en-GB.text: The police started an investigation after money disappeared from the office safe.

en-US.text: There will be an investigation to find out why the bridge fell down.

en-GB.text: The company began an investigation after workers reported safety problems in the factory.

en-US.text: Human resources started an investigation to understand complaints about conditions in the office.

en-GB.text: The government announced an investigation into how public money was spent on the project.

en-US.text: The school carried out an investigation after parents complained about the new rules.

en-GB.text: Police continue their investigation until they have enough evidence to take someone to court.

en-US.text: A long investigation finally identified the man responsible for the series of robberies.

shortDescription.en-GB: pay to use or employ something
shortDescription.en-US: pay to use or employ something

definitions.definition: To give someone a job and pay them to work for you.

en-GB.text: The company plans to hire two new engineers before the busy summer period.

en-US.text: They hired a student to answer phones and welcome visitors at the front desk.

definitions.definition: To pay money to use something for a short time, for example a car or bike.

en-GB.text: We will hire a car at the airport and drive to the hotel ourselves.

en-US.text: You can hire a bike in the city centre and return it in the evening.

en-GB.text: Shops hire extra staff before holidays when many more customers come to buy things.

en-US.text: During summer, hotels hire students to help with cleaning, cooking, and reception work.

en-GB.text: The company will hire new workers if sales increase over the next few months.

en-US.text: He wrote a clear CV to help him get hired by a large international firm.

definitions.definition: To be in front or in control, and guide other people in some activity.

en-GB.text: Our teacher will lead the trip and make sure everyone stays safe and happy.

en-US.text: Two police cars led the parade through the town on a busy Saturday.

definitions.definition: To be the person who is responsible for a team, group, or project.

en-GB.text: She leads a small team in the office and organises their daily tasks.

en-US.text: He was chosen to lead the project because he communicates clearly with everyone.

en-GB.text: A clear map can lead you through a new city without getting lost once.

en-US.text: Too much sugar can lead to health problems if people eat it every day.

en-GB.text: She was chosen to lead the team because she listens carefully and makes fair decisions.

en-US.text: Good managers lead by example and show staff how to behave in difficult situations.

shortDescription.en-GB: without a paid job at present
shortDescription.en-US: without a paid job at present

definitions.definition: Not having a job, although you are able and ready to work.

en-GB.text: She has been unemployed for six months and is looking for work every day.

en-US.text: Many unemployed people attend courses to learn new skills and find jobs.

en-GB.text: Unemployed is an adjective for people who do not have a job at present.

en-US.text: Many unemployed workers feel worried about bills and future plans for their families.

en-GB.text: The government offers courses to help unemployed people learn new skills and find jobs.

en-US.text: He registered at the job centre because he had been unemployed for several months.

shortDescription.en-GB: share or give things to many people
shortDescription.en-US: share or give things to many people

definitions.definition: To give or send things to several people or places, usually from one main place.

en-GB.text: The charity distributes food to families who need help in the winter.

en-US.text: The company distributes its products to shops in many towns across the country.

en-GB.text: Volunteers distribute water to runners during the race on hot summer days.

en-US.text: Teachers distribute the worksheets before explaining the task to the class.

en-GB.text: He works for a company that distributes books to schools across the whole region.

en-US.text: Many drivers are employed to distribute parcels from the warehouse to different towns.

en-GB.text: Big supermarkets distribute special offers through emails, apps, and printed leaflets.

en-US.text: Before opening, staff distribute price labels and signs around the shop shelves.

definitions.definition: Describing a place where customers serve themselves instead of being served by staff.

en-GB.text: We ate in a self-service restaurant where you carried your own tray to the table.

en-US.text: The supermarket has self-service checkouts where customers scan and pay for items themselves.

en-GB.text: Self-service tills mean shops need fewer cashiers but still need staff to help customers.

en-US.text: Some workers fear that self-service machines will reduce the number of available jobs.

en-GB.text: At the supermarket you can choose self-service checkouts if you have only a few items.

en-US.text: Many petrol stations are now self-service, so drivers fill their cars without staff.

definitions.definition: A formal discussion where people try to reach an agreement about money, work, or plans.

en-GB.text: The negotiation between the workers and the company continued for two long days.

en-US.text: After long negotiation, both sides agreed on a fair contract for all employees.

en-GB.text: Salary negotiation can be difficult, but it is important to ask for fair pay.

en-US.text: During negotiation with managers, workers explained why they needed better hours and pay.

en-GB.text: Lawyers used negotiation to avoid a long court case and reach agreement earlier.

en-US.text: Many legal problems end in negotiation instead of a long and expensive trial.

en-GB.text: In relationships, calm negotiation can help couples solve disagreements without shouting.

en-US.text: Parents and teenagers sometimes need negotiation to agree about rules and free time.

shortDescription.en-GB: person who repairs machines or cars
shortDescription.en-US: person who repairs machines or cars

definitions.definition: A person whose job is to repair machines, especially cars, buses, or motorbikes.

en-GB.text: The car stopped on the motorway, so we called a mechanic for help.

en-US.text: A good mechanic can explain the problem clearly and show which parts need replacing.

en-GB.text: He trained as a mechanic and quickly found work at a local garage.

en-US.text: Mechanics are in demand, so it is usually possible to find work in many towns.

en-GB.text: Being a mechanic is a practical profession that suits people who enjoy fixing things.

en-US.text: At school, he chose courses that would help him become a car mechanic later.

en-GB.text: When our bus broke down, a mechanic arrived quickly to repair the engine.

en-US.text: Before a long trip, it is wise to ask a mechanic to check your car.
